Argument: Statement1: When a society undergoes slow change, its younger members find great value in the advice of its older members. But when a society undergoes rapid change, young people think that little in the experience of their elders is relevant to them, and so do not value their advice. Statement2: Thus, we may measure the rate at which a society is changing by measuring the amount of deference its younger members show to their elders.
Premise1: The deference young people show to their elders varies according to how much the young value their elders' advice.
Premise2: How much deference young people show to their elders depends on how much of the elders' experience is practically useful to them.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: When a society undergoes slow change, its younger members find great value in the advice of its older members. But when a society undergoes rapid change, young people think that little in the experience of their elders is relevant to them, and so do not value their advice. Statement3: Thus, we may measure how much of the elders' experience is practically useful by measuring the amount of deference its younger members show to their elders.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: How much deference young people show to their elders depends on how much of the elders' experience is practically useful to them.
input_info.O: Premise1: The deference young people show to their elders varies according to how much the young value their elders' advice.
input_info.P: Statement1: When a society undergoes slow change, its younger members find great value in the advice of its older members. But when a society undergoes rapid change, young people think that little in the experience of their elders is relevant to them, and so do not value their advice. Statement2: Thus, we may measure the rate at which a society is changing by measuring the amount of deference its younger members show to their elders.

input_info.Om: Premise2: The indonesian mimic octopus engages in other forms of behavior that seem to serve no purpose, yet several marine biologists are reluctant to describe such behavior as play.
input_info.O: Premise1: The color pattern an indonesian mimic octopus assumes when a predator is nearby, but that does not match its immediate environment, has been found to parallel that of various jellyfish venomous to the octopus's predators.
input_info.P: Statement1: The indonesian mimic octopus is able to camouflage itself from predators by blending into the background. Sometimes, though, even when a predator is nearby, the mimic octopus takes on a color pattern that is not present in the immediate environment. input_info.O: Premise1: New patterns of behavior that emerge in macaque populations over the course of a few years or decades are not necessarily genetically predetermined.
input_info.P: Statement1: In 1963, a young macaque monkey was observed venturing into a hot spring to retrieve food which had fallen in. However, in the case of the great apes, repeated exposure to mirrors leads to self-directed behaviors, such as exploring the inside of the mouth, suggesting that these animals recognize the reflection as an image of self. input_info.Q: The cognitive scientist makes which of the following assumptions in the argument above?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Animals that do not exhibit msr may demonstrate a capacity for self-awareness in other ways.
input_info.O: Premise1: If an animal does not have the capacity for msr, it does not have the capacity for self-awareness.
input_info.P: Statement1: Cognitive scientist : using the pioneering work of comparative psychologist gordon gallup as a model, several studies have investigated animals'capacity for mirror self-recognition ( msr ). input_info.P: Statement1: One test to determine whether a person has been infected with tuberculosis consists of injecting the person with proteins extracted from the tuberculosis bacterium. input_info.Om: Premise2: On average, clients improve more dramatically when they receive long-term psychotherapy, a year or longer in duration, than when clients receive short-term psychotherapy.
input_info.O: Premise1: The methods by which the studies measured whether clients improved primarily concerned immediate symptom relief and failed to address other important kinds of improvement.
input_info.P: Statement1: Researcher : a number of studies have suggested that, on average, clients in short-term psychotherapy show similar levels of improvement regardless of the kind of psychotherapy they receive. Statement2: So any client improvement in short-term psychotherapy must be the result of some aspect or aspects of therapy that are common to all psychotherapies -- for example, the presence of someone who listens and gives attention to the client.

input_info.P: Statement1: Being articulate has been equated with having a large vocabulary. input_info.Om: Premise2: Consumers are more likely to respond to oral surveys than they are to respond to written questionnaires.
input_info.O: Premise1: Even consumers who are unable to explain their preference for or rejection of particular brands reveal which brands they are considering by picking up and putting down products while they are shopping.
input_info.P: Statement1: Market research traditionally entails surveying consumers about why they buy and use particular products and brands. Statement2: Observational research -- actually watching consumers shopping and interacting with products -- is now increasingly used by market researchers to supplement surveys. Statement3: Market researchers claim that observational research yields information about consumer behavior that surveys alone can not provide.

Premise2: No indigenous population of any other bird species apart from the endangered owls is threatened by the gray squirrels.

Argument: Statement1: Studies show that the most creative engineers get their best and most useful ideas only after doodling and jotting down what turn out to be outlandish ideas. Statement2: These experts argue that this undesirable consequence would be avoided if computer programs for engineering work included simulated notepads that would allow engineers to suspend their" serious"work on the computer, type up outlandish ideas, and then quickly return to their original work.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the experts' reasoning depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: No engineers who work with computers keep paper and pencils near their computers in order to doodle and jot down ideas.
input_info.O: Premise1: The physical act of working on paper is not essential in providing engineers with the benefits that can be gained by doodling.
input_info.P: Statement1: Studies show that the most creative engineers get their best and most useful ideas only after doodling and jotting down what turn out to be outlandish ideas. Statement2: These experts argue that this undesirable consequence would be avoided if computer programs for engineering work included simulated notepads that would allow engineers to suspend their" serious"work on the computer, type up outlandish ideas, and then quickly return to their original work.

instruction: In the following, you will see an argument and 2 premises, where Premise 1 provides a necessary assumption to the Argument. Argument: Statement1: In 1563, in florence's palazzo vecchio, giorgio vasari built in front of an existing wall a new wall on which he painted a mural. Statement2: Investigators recently discovered a gap between vasari's wall and the original, large enough to have preserved anything painted on the original. Statement3: Historians believe that leonardo da vinci had painted, but left unfinished, a mural on the original wall ; some historians had also believed that by 1563 the mural had been destroyed. Statement4: However, it is known that in the late 1560s, when renovating another building, santa marianovella, vasari built a facade over its frescoes, and the frescoes were thereby preserved. Statement5: Thus, leonardo's palazzo vecchio mural probably still exists behind vasari's wall.

Premise2: Leonardo would probably have completed the palazzo vecchio mural if he had had the opportunity to do so.

input_info.O: Premise1: Vasari probably would not have built the palazzo vecchio wall with a gap behind it except to preserve something behind the new wall.
input_info.P: Statement1: In 1563, in florence's palazzo vecchio, giorgio vasari built in front of an existing wall a new wall on which he painted a mural. Statement2: Investigators recently discovered a gap between vasari's wall and the original, large enough to have preserved anything painted on the original. Statement2: It is claimed that this practice delays public access to potentially beneficial information that, in extreme instances, could save lives. input_info.P: Statement1: Scientists have shown that older bees, which usually forage outside the hive for food, tend to have larger brains than do younger bees, which usually do not forage but instead remain in the hive to tend to newly hatched bees. Argument: Statement1: A survey of entrepreneurs who started companies last year shows that while virtually all did substantial preparatory research and planning, only half used that work to produce a formal business plan. Statement2: Since, on average, the entrepreneurs without formal plans secured the capital they needed in half the time of those with plans, these survey results indicate that, in general, formal plans did not help the entrepreneurs who produced them to secure the capital they needed.
Premise1: Among the entrepreneurs surveyed, those who did not produce formal business plans sought and received a much larger proportion of their capital from investors with whom they had a long-standing business relationship.
Premise2: Companies started by entrepreneurs who had used formal business plans to attract investment were on the whole as profitable in their first year as were companies started by entrepreneurs who had not produced such plans.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: A survey of entrepreneurs who started companies last year shows that while virtually all did substantial preparatory research and planning, only half used that work to produce a formal business plan. Statement2: Although, on average, the entrepreneurs without formal plans secured the capital they needed in half the time of those with plans, these survey results do not indicate that, in fact, formal plans help the entrepreneurs who produced them to secure the profit they needed.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Companies started by entrepreneurs who had used formal business plans to attract investment were on the whole as profitable in their first year as were companies started by entrepreneurs who had not produced such plans.
input_info.O: Premise1: Among the entrepreneurs surveyed, those who did not produce formal business plans sought and received a much larger proportion of their capital from investors with whom they had a long-standing business relationship.
input_info.P: Statement1: A survey of entrepreneurs who started companies last year shows that while virtually all did substantial preparatory research and planning, only half used that work to produce a formal business plan. Statement2: Since, on average, the entrepreneurs without formal plans secured the capital they needed in half the time of those with plans, these survey results indicate that, in general, formal plans did not help the entrepreneurs who produced them to secure the capital they needed.

instruction: In the following, you will see an argument and 2 premises, where Premise 1 strengthens the Argument. Argument: Statement1: On the caribbean island of guadeloupe, a researcher examined 35 patients with atypical parkinson's disease and compared their eating habits to those of 65 healthy adults. Statement2: She found that all of the patients with atypical parkinson's regularly ate the tropical fruits soursop, custard apple, and pomme cannelle, whereas only 10 of the healthy adults regularly ate these fruits. Statement3: From this, she concluded that eating these fruits causes atypical parkinson's.
Premise1: For many of the atypical parkinson's patients, their symptoms stopped getting worse, and in some cases actually abated, when they stopped eating soursop, custard apple, and pomme cannelle.
Premise2: The 10 healthy adults who regularly ate soursop, custard apple, and pomme cannelle ate significantly greater quantities of these fruits, on average, than did the 35 atypical parkinson's patients.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: On the caribbean island of guadeloupe, a researcher examined 35 patients with atypical parkinson's disease and compared their eating habits to those of 65 healthy adults. Statement2: She found that all of the patients with atypical parkinson's regularly ate the tropical fruits soursop, custard apple, and pomme cannelle, but 10 of the healthy adults regularly ate even more. Statement3: From this, she couldn't conclude that eating these fruits causes atypical parkinson's.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the researcher's reasoning?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The 10 healthy adults who regularly ate soursop, custard apple, and pomme cannelle ate significantly greater quantities of these fruits, on average, than did the 35 atypical parkinson's patients.
input_info.O: Premise1: For many of the atypical parkinson's patients, their symptoms stopped getting worse, and in some cases actually abated, when they stopped eating soursop, custard apple, and pomme cannelle.
input_info.P: Statement1: On the caribbean island of guadeloupe, a researcher examined 35 patients with atypical parkinson's disease and compared their eating habits to those of 65 healthy adults. Statement2: She found that all of the patients with atypical parkinson's regularly ate the tropical fruits soursop, custard apple, and pomme cannelle, whereas only 10 of the healthy adults regularly ate these fruits. Statement3: From this, she concluded that eating these fruits causes atypical parkinson's.

input_info.P: Statement1: Chronic fatigue syndrome is characterized by prolonged fatigue, muscular pain, and neurological problems. Statement2: It is not known whether these symptoms are all caused by a single virus or whether each symptom is the result of a separate viral infection. Although the specific antiviral effects of this drug are unknown, it has lessened the severity of all of the symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome. Statement4: Thus there is evidence that chronic fatigue syndrome is, in fact, caused by one virus.
